I was sitting today, feeling heavy after a bad meal from a takeout place. I was smoking when suddenly Marfa Petrovna came in. She looked nice in a new green silk dress with a long train. 

“Good day, Arkady Ivanovitch! How do you like my dress? Aniska can’t make one like this.” (Aniska was a dressmaker from the country, one of our old serf girls who learned in Moscow and was pretty.) She turned around in front of me. I looked at her dress and then carefully at her face. 

“I wonder why you bother coming to me about such small things, Marfa Petrovna.” 

“Goodness, you won’t let anyone worry you about anything!” To tease her, I said, “I want to get married, Marfa Petrovna.” 

“That’s just like you, Arkady Ivanovitch. It doesn’t look good for you to look for a bride when you’ve just buried your wife. And if you could choose well, at least, but I know it won’t make you or her happy. You’ll just be a joke to everyone.” Then she left, and her train made a rustling sound. Isn’t that silly? 

“But maybe you’re lying?” Raskolnikov said. 

“I rarely lie,” Svidrigaïlov replied thoughtfully, not seeming to notice the rudeness of the question. 

“And in the past, have you ever seen ghosts?” 

“Y-yes, I have seen them, but only once in my life, six years ago. I had a serf named Filka; right after his burial, I called out without thinking, ‘Filka, my pipe!’ He came in and went to the cupboard where my pipes were. I sat still and thought, ‘He’s doing this out of revenge,’ because we had a big fight just before he died. ‘How dare you come in with a hole in...”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Marfa Petrovna visits Svidrigaïlov, showcasing her new dress and teasing him about seeking a bride shortly after his wife's death.
